item.title: Survey Points to Challenges NATO Faces Over Russia
item.description: A substantial number of Europeans do not believe that their own countries should rush to defend an ally against attack, according to a comprehensive survey to be made public on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: A Russia-backed rebel in eastern Ukraine on Tuesday. Russia has used "hybrid war" tactics to mask its operations there.

item.title: U.S. Embracing a New Approach on Battling ISIS in Iraq
item.description: The effort to retake Ramadi and push back the Islamic State effectively delays plans to recapture the city of Mosul this year.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey in Tel Aviv on Tuesday. He met with Defense Minister Moshi Yaalon and other Israeli officials.

item.title: South Korean Leader Postpones U.S. Trip Amid MERS Outbreak
item.description: President Park Geun-hye was scheduled to meet with President Obama next week, but an aide cited “the anxiety among the people over the situation” at home.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Pedestrians wore protective masks in Seoul on Tuesday. Nearly 2,900 people in the country have been isolated as a precaution.

item.title: Questionable Expenses by Lawmakers in Other Countries
item.description: From private moat cleanings to a sadomasochistic performance, the reimbursement claims of lawmakers from other countries make the Canadian Senate’s look tame.
item.dc:creator: KARIN ROBERTS

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: State Dept. Says It Won’t Meet With Brotherhood Group in Washington
item.description: United States officials will not meet with visiting members of a delegation from Egypt’s Muslim Brotherhood, a State Department spokesman said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: 11 Sentenced to Death in Cases Tied to Soccer Riot That Killed Dozens
item.description: An Egyptian criminal court from the city of Port Said sentenced 11 people to death on Tuesday for their roles in a 2012 soccer riot there that killed more than 70 people and injured hundreds in Egypt’s worst-ever soccer disaster.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Romania: Premier Retains Immunity
item.description: Prime Minister Victor Ponta was named last week as a suspect in a criminal investigation that includes money laundering and being an accomplice to tax evasion.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Italy: Doctor Abducted in Libya Is Freed
item.description: Ignazio Scaravilli, was in good condition in Tripoli, awaiting his return to Italy.

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: U.N. Warns That Migrants May Overwhelm Tourist Island of Lesbos
item.description: Roughly 600 refugees a day were arriving in the Greek islands, and that half of them were coming ashore in Lesbos, a picturesque tourist destination ill equipped to handle the flow.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Business Briefing: Global Airlines Move Toward Even Smaller Carry-On Bags
item.description: Airlines recommended even smaller carry-on bags in an effort to free up space in overhead bins. The guideline is not binding.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Rebels Seize Syrian Army Base in a Blow to Assad
item.description: The Southern Front of the Free Syrian Army declared that they had seized the base in a six-hour lightning advance, suggesting the group still has some strength.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Southern Front of the Free Syrian Army
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: ISIS Stages Attacks in Iraq and Libya, Despite U.S. Airstrikes
item.description: In Libya, the Islamic State captured a critical power plant, while in Iraq, gunmen in suicide vests attacked a council building in Amiriyat al Falluja, southwest of Baghdad.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Shiite fighters in Baiji, north of Baghdad, are fighting with Iraqi forces against the Islamic State.

item.title: Sales to Mahan Air Blacklisted by U.S. Hang Over Iran Talks
item.description: With a June 30 deadline looming to reach a nuclear agreement, Iran and the United States appeared headed toward a possible confrontation over the airline’s purchase of nine used Airbus jetliners.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: SOCO Oil Company Paid Large Sums to Officer in Congo, Activists Say
item.description: New documents suggest the conflict between economic development and environmental preservation in Africa’s oldest national park endures.
item.category: Virunga National Park (Congo, Democratic Republic of)
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Virunga National Park, the oldest in Africa, has been the center of an intense conflict between the forces of economic development and environmental conservation.

item.title: In Germany, Grass-Roots Opposition to a European-U.S. Trade Deal
item.description: While Germany is one of the countries most likely to benefit from such a deal, polls show that the country has among the strongest public opposition.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Campact protest in Berlin this year featured a dragon puffing imitation herbicide, with a body modeled on a spray bottle from the agrochemical giant Monsanto.

item.title: Marie-Louise Carven, Designer of Accessible Chic, Dies at 105
item.description: The brand Mrs. Carven built has become synonymous with the rise of “contemporary,” midprice, accessible clothing with runway credibility, in French fashion.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA FRIEDMAN
item.media:description: Marie-Louise Carven in 1964. She was also a skilled marketer.

item.title: Indian Woman Being Treated in U.S. for Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis
item.description: The woman could be at a federal hospital for a year or more, and health officials have tried to find who was in contact with her in three states and on a plane.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.dc:creator: DENISE GRADY
item.media:credit: Steve Kagan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Susan Karras, the communicable disease coordinator for McHenry County, outside Chicago, where a TB patient visited.

item.title: Amid MERS Outbreak, Readers Reflect on South Korean Hospitals
item.description: Responding on Facebook, readers who either live or have spent time in South Korea shared their experiences of the hospitals there.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: Canadian Senators’ Expenses Under Investigation After Auditor’s Report
item.description: The findings, involving current and former members, threaten to erode the standing of the Senate, which is under a cloud from a corruption trial.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Women’s Rights Battle, a Call to Underarms
item.description: Xiao Meili is conducting a photo contest to challenge a growing belief in China that a woman must have hair-free armpits to be attractive.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO and DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Xiao Meili, who organized the contest to fight social pressure for women to shave their armpits, posted her own photo.
